title: Commuter’s fury at passenger who plonked backside on table inches from his face
text:
Paul Neuhardt snapped a photo of the ‘inconsiderate’ passenger’s backside inches from his face (Picture: Kennedy News)

A commuter slammed a ‘crass’ fellow train passenger who shunned empty seats to rest his backside on a table just inches from his face.

Paul Neuhardt, 57, took a photo of the ‘inconsiderate’ traveller during his morning commute into London back on October 8.

He said it wasn’t an uncommon thing to do as the Southern journey usually gets quite crowded, but added that this encroachment was ‘particularly egregious’ because there were still spare seats scattered around the carriage.

The headphone-wearing man did not even ask permission or say thank you after swooping in and taking his perch, the father-of four said.

Paul tweeted a photo of the passenger with the caption: ‘No, really, have a seat. I don’t mind having your bum as my view for the rest of this train ride. By all means, have a seat on the table.’

Paul bemoaned having the man’s bum as his view for the rest of the journey (Picture: Kennedy News)

Paul, with wife Trish, said it was ‘particularly egregious’ in light of the empty seats scattered around (Picture: Kennedy News)

Paul, from Tadworth in Surrey, said it took the man ‘four seconds tops’ to beeline for his table after getting on the 30-minute service to London Bridge.

The operations manager said: ‘I thought it was both crass and a bit inconsiderate.

‘I thought it was very egocentric and very self-centered on his part, particularly when as he sat down the thing visibly bent.

‘Not only was he doing this rather rudely and inconsiderately but he was potentially causing damage to the table.

‘He had to have been able to tell that it was giving way under his weight, and it made snapping and popping noises.

‘If we hit a bump or went around a corner pretty hard you could hear it groaning and making those noises.

‘It’s not uncommon for someone to get on and as the train starts to crowd up just plop down and use that table right in front of people as a seat.

‘This particular one I thought was particularly egregious because there were empty seats on the train.

‘He paid no attention to the fact that there was somebody at the table, that there was somebody who had something on the table, or that the table – meant for laptops or books – creaked and made cracking noises under his weight.’

The Southern journey regularly fills up and there aren’t many handrails to cling onto, Paul said (Picture: Getty Images)

Paul put the stunt down to ‘habit’ as the man was probably used to the train being full by that stage of the journey and there aren’t very many handrails to cling onto.

‘It’s a large space – there’s no place to [use] a handrail,’ he continued.

‘Somebody sees a place to park their backside for the next 40 minutes and rather than stand or show consideration to others, they take a load off.

‘I admit I didn’t say anything to him, I just sat there and fumed and took a picture of his backside on the table.’

His social media post garnered more than 200 comments, with Gordon Hodge observing: ‘Tables are made for glasses and not for stinking arses.’

Another, Charlotte Dales, said: ‘This would annoy me so much. Such an invasion of personal space!’

Dan Dodd simply remarked: ‘What an arsehole.’
